captions.text:
I had a curious recurring interaction this week. 
&quot;Hey, Yahtz, are you playing Borderlands 4?&quot;

someone asks. &quot;Yes, I am,&quot; I reply. &quot;How&#39;s it 
running for you?&quot; comes the follow-up question.

&quot;Like complete dogshit, since you ask,&quot; I reply, 
and then a tangible sense of relief washes over us

both. Phew, we don&#39;t need to buy a new graphics 
card or upgrade our drivers or dig the worms

out of our eyeballs that are making it look like 
the frame rate&#39;s dropping like globules of spunk

from your mum&#39;s reading glasses; the game&#39;s just 
optimized for shit. And then a strange solidarity

develops between us as we light-heartedly swap 
stories about our favorite bugs and speculate

on which specific parts of the game suffered 
the most from the impacts of Randy Pitchford&#39;s

wildly swinging penis. The only thing that 
should be crashing to desktop this much is

an office worker with narcolepsy. And when a 
video game world has bottomless pit hazards,

it would be useful if the devs could remember 
to put killboxes in those bottomless pits so I

don&#39;t find myself floating in mid-void 
under the map, kicking my little legs,

trying to bounce a grenade off an invisible 
wall in the hopes of ending my farce of a life.

But yeah, Borderlands 4, Bored of this Bland 
Snore, if you will, the latest instalment in

Gearbox&#39;s signature sci-fi FPS franchise that 
offers an idiosyncratic four-pronged experience:

shooting, looting, hooting, and tooting. Hooting 
meaning lots of very facetious quippy dialogue

between wacky characters, and tooting meaning 
me reacting to all of said dialogue like it&#39;s a

great big fart in my face. Actually, Borderlands 4 
seems to have leaned slightly away from the wacky

quippy thing compared to Borderlands 3, at least. 
It&#39;s still got a lot of quipping, and it&#39;s still

occupying some blasted comedy no man&#39;s land, but 
it&#39;s fucking Borderlands. You can&#39;t expect less;

that would be like expecting a band from 
California to write a song that isn&#39;t about

California for once. Having leaned slightly 
away from something, one might question what

Borderlands 4 leans into instead, and the answer 
is: nothing. Just sort of sticks straight up now,

like a confused hand in a remedial classroom. 
See, I didn&#39;t want to dwell on the bugs and

the shitty optimization because, as ever, that 
shit could hypothetically be fixed in post with

some intensive patching and maybe finally getting 
around to Randy Pitchford&#39;s dick removal surgery.

But when a game is on the high end of tech 
requirements, there&#39;s this tacit understanding

that this is the price of living on the cutting 
edge of hot new games, and if Borderlands 4

is the cutting edge, it&#39;s gonna result in a 
very disappointing birthday cake experience;

all the frosting&#39;s gonna get squeezed out the 
sides. Even while I&#39;m hearing my computer fan

roaring like the sustained scream of a kamikaze 
pilot, Borderlands 4 isn&#39;t doing much to show off

the excessive power usage. Does it look nice? 
I guess. Not especially. Usual art style that

looks like Fallout wiped its arse on the Mad Max 
Saturday morning cartoon. Does it have tons of

exciting new features? Er. It&#39;s got a contextual 
grappling hook. Hook being precisely the wrong

word. You know what&#39;s depressing is that there 
was a time when this might&#39;ve shivered me nads,

but frankly, Just Cause 2 pretty much did 
everything I wanted done with grappling hooks,

and that was 15 Ferrero Rocher-scoffing years 
ago. I suppose Borderlands 4 feels kinda new

for a Borderlands game. Unfortunately, it would 
also feel very, very old for a Far Cry game. Is

this all we are now, triple A games? The same 
toy box every few months with the contents

slightly rearranged? Things haven&#39;t been the 
same since you sanded down Lara Croft&#39;s tits.

It starts out the usual Borderlands experience: 
pick one of four colorful, loudmouthed mercenaries

introduced by an opening music video like 
Guy Ritchie got hired to adapt Masters of

the Universe, but then the cast are imprisoned in 
a big, seamless open world by a high-class villain

who thinks we&#39;ve got nothing better to do all day 
than listen to him gab off about the futility of

our struggle in the face of his perfection. 
Which is where the Far Cry comparison begins,

although they seem to have forgotten the 
&quot;charismatic and competent&quot; parts of the

standard Far Cry villain template. The world is 
divided between three areas: one of them&#39;s grassy,

one of them&#39;s deserty, and the other one&#39;s snowy, 
obviously. What, you think your money warrants

more creativity than that, you lowly worm? And 
of course, each one is governed by one of the

main villain&#39;s lead henchmen. One of them&#39;s the 
tough one, one of them&#39;s the smart one, and one

of them&#39;s the mad one. Hey, it was the same deal 
with the three gods in Eternal Darkness, wasn&#39;t

it? Boy, that was an interesting game. Let&#39;s dwell 
on those happier times for a moment. Of the three

sub-bosses, two are actively working against the 
main villain and the third is so incompetent,

the big villain basically cheers you on while 
you&#39;re doing him in. &quot;Hey, thanks for reducing

my Christmas present budget, and incidentally, 
you will never defeat me, bwa ha ha.&quot;

So, after I did defeat him in the big story 
climax after a short two-phase exchange in

which he decided to bring slow-moving triangle 
lasers to a gunfight, I said aloud, &quot;Boy, from

the way you were going on, I really thought that 
would be harder. Props for self-esteem, I guess;

I should switch to your therapist.&quot; But I wasn&#39;t 
stupid; we still hadn&#39;t had a boss fight with the

other dude who&#39;d shown up as a surprise villain 
not long earlier and demonstrated incredible

combat skills, so after skipping the credits 
roll, I was returned to gameplay in front of a

big portal with the game going, &quot;Hey, just walk 
through this door, nothing sus.&quot; And of course,

we get pulled into the cosmic realm 
where we fight the real final boss in

space as they subject us to all the nightmarish 
horrors of their—oh, they died already. Man,

some of the random shootouts earlier were 
harder than this. It&#39;s almost like most

of the challenge in a shooter comes from finding 
cover and prioritizing targets, and therefore, if

there&#39;s only one dude shooting at you and for you 
to shoot at, you can just hold the mouse pointer

over them and wait for them to stop moving. Was 
that really what this was all leading up to, game?

&quot;Oh, I couldn&#39;t possibly comment. Anyway, now 
story mode&#39;s over; let me walk you through all the

ways you&#39;re going to be grinding to make numbers 
go up for the rest of your fucking life.&quot; Er,

how about piss off, Borderlands 4? I&#39;m mad now. 
It&#39;s not just dreary, it&#39;s fucking insolent to

expect people to buy top-of-the-line hardware 
to play the same repetitive drivel as always.

Nothing in Borderlands 4 stands out as a 
must-see moment or unique selling point.

The most that could be said is that it once 
again presents lots of wonderful opportunities

to shoot Jason Voorhees in a scrapyard 
as well as shoot Jason Voorhees&#39; dog in

the field behind the scrapyard, and if you ask 
nicely, also some robots in the decommissioned

Amazon warehouse that the city authority will 
shortly be rezoning as a scrapyard, and you

could recreate the experience playing basically 
any other Borderlands game. Or, alternatively,

another repetitive shooter game entirely as 
long as you spend the whole time listening

to a looping tape of an ill-conceived improv 
comedy night hosted by professional wrestlers.
